data.title: Question on Build and Run From Source instructions: Node version
data.body:
The wiki [instructions](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source) say that I'll need Node.JS, at least version 5.10.   For unrelated reasons, I'm reluctant to install anything later than the latest [LTS](https://github.com/nodejs/LTS#lts_schedule) release (v4.4.5) on the default PATH on my dev system.   

Is v5.10 still the best release for working on vscode?   Any reason not use the 'Current' v6.2.2?

Is it possible to setup and use a side-by-side version of Node.js for the purpose of contributing to vscode on the same machine where latest LTS-compatible tools are built?     Any recommended approach would be helpful?

TIA

data.title: Emmet: support all the features
data.body:
Now we only support:
- Expand Abbreviation
- Wrap with Abbreviation
- Remove Tag
- Update Tag

@egamma Are you planning to support [other features](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/master/lib/action/main.js#L75-L95)? I can submit a PR.

data.title: Multiple-Integrated-Terminal discoverability/usability issues
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (62f0272219dc72fda5246d330640e6af52a10cd0, 2016-06-20T22:45:16.666Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 - Windows 10 14342.1000 (Insider)

Hitting the hotkey (Ctrl+Shift+`) again seems to refresh the Integrated Terminal window and the content of the already opened window disappears. I figured that this opened a fresh terminal -- but because there is no UI element that indicates how many terminals are open or which terminal I am on, I assumed it just replaced the old terminal and there was no way back.

The plus button apparently functions the same way, but initially I had no idea what it would do. Clicking it caused the terminal to reset but I wasn't sure why until I hovered over the button to read the pop-up text. 

Considering that there is no UI concept of tabs, multiple terminals, or ordering of the same, the back and forward buttons are similarly hard to reason about. They also apparently cycle around but since I have no idea how many terminals I have open without 

A "minus" button does not say to me that it would "close" a terminal. Not sure what I was expecting it to do. I understand there would be an overlap with the X for close (X already closes the pane).

It was not clear to me whether pressing the X (hover text: "Close") would close all terminals or just close "hide" the Terminal pane. The text should probably be changed to something like "Hide Integrated Terminal" to line up better with the text for Ctrl+` in the command palette:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16216563/8ff9a2da-3720-11e6-833a-72bba619fd8d.png)

I know the hotkey Ctrl+` is there, but does it make sense for Ctrl+Shift+` it to open a fresh terminal when there is already a terminal open? Maybe it should pop open the Terminal pane first and not open a fresh terminal?

data.title: No way to apply four slashes //// using shortcut

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.3

Description:
I use four slashes //// to differentiate commented out code from actual comments but vscode inserts a space between two slashes // // if I apply line comment twice.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set focus on a line in the editor
2. Press cmd+k, cmd+c to comment out the code with //
3. Press cmd+k, cmd+c again

(Expected)
//// var foo;

(Actual)
// // var foo;

(Related link)
On four slashes usage
http://stylecop.soyuz5.com/SA1626.html

Thanks for consideration!

data.title: Bogus "Canceled" error message when stopped debugging in certain scenarios
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: All

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start debugging with a debug adapter which won't send a response (e.g., there's a bug in the debug adapter, or the debug adapter is waiting for an external event (attaching a debugger to it)) for a request from VSCode.
2. When stopping the debug session (`disconnect` request), there is an error popping up in the VSCode UI that reads "`Canceled`".

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16213429/207eaac0-3704-11e6-8fd7-05ea636aad21.png)

Expected: debugging stops cleanly as far as the user can tell.

I spent a short amount of time looking into this to see if the error message was coming from the debug adapter somehow. I found that the `disconnect` request calls `cancel()` on all sent promises.
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/c5429332d4ac326a94a6c5e87fffefcb14d10e84/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/node/rawDebugSession.ts#L261

This is the exception that is causing the error in the VSCode UI
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/bfb5b806e4f0328102bde3fd8750e63c66c2f19a/src/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js#L1654

It doesn't seem like the promises that are being pushed into `sentPromises` have an `onCancel()` handler
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/81050abedbe54597b9506609eb5b7cb916ddc9c6/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/node/v8Protocol.ts#L44
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/bfb5b806e4f0328102bde3fd8750e63c66c2f19a/src/vs/base/common/winjs.base.d.ts#L64

@isidorn

data.title: Allow configuring language explicitly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1 (1.2.1)
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set Mac OS X to e.g. German locale
2. Start VS Code
3. VS Code is now localized in German, including configuration files

I'd like an option to control localization myself. I like my OS in German, but would strongly prefer to keep all developer tools (like VS Code) in English.

data.title: Why do we differentiate preview open files with italic font?
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 7

I'm not sure there is benefit differentiating preview open file (with italic font) from fully opened files. What information does this give the user and how would they act on it?

Italics in the heading doesn't look good on some lower resolution monitors.
![italic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12818376/16212473/b8a4a302-36fc-11e6-95f4-74650fe4f5a9.png)

data.title: Reconsider using the term "editor" for files and views on files
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 7

I think users will be confused by the term "editor" for a view on a file. Users think of VS Code as an "editor" of their "files".

I noticed this confusion when I started on the June_2016.md release notes.  We have sentences like "As a preparation for enabling Tabs in the workbench, we revisited how you can interact with editors in VS Code. Many users coming from other editors were confused by some of the editor behavior in VS Code:"

As you can see above, we mention editor three times with two different meanings; as the tool VS Code and as open files.

This is more understandable as "As a preparation for enabling Tabs in the workbench, we revisited how you can interact with files in VS Code. Many users coming from other editors were confused by some of the open file behavior in VS Code:"

I recommend we use "OPEN FILES" instead of "OPEN EDITORS".  

I don't see too many other uses of the term "editor" in the UI but some commands would need to be renamed:
Preview command **Keep Editor**  -> **Open File** - I think "Keep Editor" will be confusing
**File** > **Close Editor** -> **File** > **Close File** - we no longer close the entire editor window, just the last file. 

Using "editor" for the three editor windows seems fine so it make senses to talk about "editor groups" but these are groups of files not groups of "editors".

data.title: Focus and scroll issues with built-in terminal window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:

Focus issue:
1. Open the terminal window
2. Run a command
3. Click or select some text in the window above
4. Try and type, it doesn't do anything
5. Click or select a second time and the text will respond as expected

Scroll issue
1. Have enough output in the terminal window that causes it to scroll
2. Scroll to the top of that terminal window
3. Try and and scroll down, it's locked up.
4. hit up or down arrows and focus will jump back to input and scroll will work again

data.title: Install Extension fails: does not properly install node_modules into extension folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.3.0
- OS Version:
  Mac OS 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install extension ForceCode
2. Open in Visual Studio Code - Insiders Build v. 1.3.0 while not debugging.
3. Attempt to activate extension with compile
4. Get the error 'No handler found for the command ...' An extension might be missing an activation event.

Notes:  Extension works properly when `npm install` is run in the extension directory.  When it's packaged or published and installed in the client, not all dependencies get installed, leading to "missing module" showing up in the developer console.  I've added about 30 low level dependencies, and it currently works on one of my macs and not the other, they are the same versions and OSs

data.title: Windows: F1 should open some kind of help and not command pallette

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

My keyboard has the word **Help** stamped right on the **F1** key's legend.   As a long-term Windows and Visual Studio user, I expect **F1** to mean Help!   Preferably context-sensitive help that focuses on what I'm focused on (DWIM.)  So for example, when I'm editing README.md, I sort of hope that F1 to produce a Markdown cheat sheet.

While I appreciate the command pallet that F1 currently invokes in VSCode, it can be invoked by other means (e.g. **Ctrl+Shift+P**), and some interesting expectations seem to have come from mapping F1 to the command pallet.   #7269.  

I couldn't agree more that an F key shortcut is justified, perhaps **F4** would be a better mapping for displaying the command pallet given the traditional Windows UI guidelines.   **F4** has long been used in contexts such as a combo-box to display a list of alternatives.   See [Guidelines for Keyboard User Interface Design](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms971323.aspx).   Also try, for example, pressing **F4** in the windows explorer, internet explorer, etc.

data.title: Variable view update on variable changes from the debugger console
data.body:
Copying an issue opened in our vscode-cordova repo, because it appears to be VSCode-specific:

> During a debugging session which stopped at a breakpoint, changing the value of a variable through the debugger console does not update the variable's value in the variables view.
> The update can first be seen after stepping forward

I was able to repro this using VSCode 1.2.1 with the built-in NodeJS debugger.

Is this by design?

data.title: Tab context menu actions to open a new tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1. Context menu on a tab header
2. Only actions to close, I would expect some actions to open a new tab (new, open) - similar to sublime and chrome

data.title: Double click on empty header area should open a new tab
data.body:
We need some action to easily open a new tab via mouse. Chrome has that small square and sublime has double click on empty area to open a new tab.

Since I might not like rendering the extra square, I vote for double click on empty header area opens a new tab - same as sublime.

data.title: / should focus `Help > Search`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

/ should focus `Help > Search`, as it's the default behavior on OS X and it isn't mapped to anything else.

data.title: Tmux and integrated terminal
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.2.1 (fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761) - OS Version: OS X 10.11.5 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open the terminal window (cmd+`) 2. Open a new tmux session (`tmux new`) 3. Close the terminal window (cmd+`) 4. Open the terminal window (cmd+`) When using tmux in terminal window everything works fine, but as soon as you close the window and reopen it the rendering is broken. If you hit `ctrl+d` several times to close the terminal in the and you have a `Cannot set property innerHTML of undefined` error and end up having to `reload window` for the terminal to be working again. ![vscode-tmux-terminal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1788218/16190203/68737e9e-36de-11e6-9dd3-0208e32de7a1.gif) You can't see it obviously but in this gif, when I reopen the terminal window I did another `ls`.

data.title: Diff tool will not identify tabs additions if there is any real code change
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Put some tabs before code like below
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/16189801/c9257c76-370e-11e6-849a-a02d7ad31015.png)
2. Add some real code change
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/16189818/dd58dd0a-370e-11e6-86f2-9e34ecaae5d1.png)

With this tiny bug, you might check in additional tabs/control characters (this happens a lot when your editor has auto-format turned on) blindly and people might don't love you any more :cry:

data.title: Fix markdown issues
data.body:
The markdown plist language include section is generated by scripts I wrote, no idea why PHP was missing in the beginning. But now I bring it back. Fixes #3746 .

The second commit is adding brackets auto-closing in markdown. Fixes #6113 .
